revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
'''Project Sunshine for Japan''' (motto “Your colours can brighten the land of the rising sun again!”) is a worldwide campaign by Mansoureh (Mana) Rahnama <ref>http://projectsunshineforjapan.wordpress.com/about/ Website Project Sunshine for Japan (Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://en.red-dot.org/5007.html reddot design about Project Sunshine for Japan; 15 February 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> in Dortmund, Germany. Rahnama started the networking project in April 2011 in the form of a [[poster]] competition in support of the survivors of the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] [[Japan]] in March 2011.<ref>http://en.red-dot.org/4522.html red dot design museum, 20 April 2011 (red dot design. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.page-online.de/emag/szene/artikel/posterwettbewerb_sunshine_for_japan (Page German Design Magazine. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tokyo-duesseldorf.de/?p=756 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222013100/http://tokyo-duesseldorf.de/?p=756 |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }} Tokyo – Düsseldorf und zurück, 1 June 2011 (Tokyo-Düsseldorf Blog. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.posterpage.ch/compet/11jap.htm Rene Warner, May 31, 2011 (Posterpage.ch. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.blogilvy.nl/2011/05/03/project-sunshine-for-japan/{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (Blogilvy 3 May 2011. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.talkmagazine.net/images/issues/TalkMagazine.No.16.pdf (Talkmagazine 8 August 2011. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref>
== History ==
Around 400 international designers from 40 countries participated in the competition.<ref>http://en.red-dot.org/5007.html (reddot design. 15 February 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> A jury (Pamela Campagna + Thomas A. Scheiderbauer (Italy), Holger Jacobs (Great Britain), Wilfried Korfmacher (Germany), Uwe Loesch (Germany),<ref>http://en.red-dot.org/4522.html (red dot website. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> Luba Lukova (USA), John Moore (Venezuela), [[Woody Pirtle]] (USA), Christopher Scott (Ireland),<ref>http://christopherscottdesigner.com/work/project-sunshine-for-japan/ (Christopher Scott about Project Sunshine for Japan. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> and Shinoske Sugisaki (Japan))<ref>http://www.shinn.co.jp/profile/shinnoskesugisaki/ Shinoske Sugisaki. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> selected the 100 best posters.<ref name="projectsunshineforjapan.wordpress.com">http://projectsunshineforjapan.wordpress.com/the-winner-of-the-100-selected-poster-2/ (Website Project Sunshine. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://dmirilen.livejournal.com/44635.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120221034227/http://dmirilen.livejournal.com/44635.html |archivedate=2012-02-21 |df= }} (Website Dmirilen. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.vc.nagaoka-id.ac.jp/project-sunshine-for-japan-%E5%8F%82%E5%8A%A0%EF%BC%8F%E5%BE%A1%E6%B3%95%E5%B7%9D.html (Tetsuro Minorikawa at [[Nagaoka Institute of Design]] in japanese language, 3 May 2012. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> Six posters received recognition and awards (Mark Andersen (USA), Kristina Jovanovic (Serbia), Scott Laserow (USA), Zafar Lehimle (Turkey), Yossi Lemel (Israel), and Tristan Schmitz<ref>http://tristanschmitz.tumblr.com/page/4 Tristan Schmitz</ref> (Germany).<ref name="projectsunshineforjapan.wordpress.com"/> The posters were presented in several exhibitions all over the world.<ref>http://en.red-dot.org/5007.html (reddot design 15 February 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014).</ref><ref>https://en.book-fair.com/networking/search_find/companies/listEvent.aspx?PageRequestId=da894178-aeff-4760-a845-2bab0166aaa6&42abdb54-9d4d-4c94-a338-b0e96bcf9e73=08e41691-65af-4e7e-b51a-24091b63791f (Website Frankfurt Book Fair October 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref>
== The Book ==
'''Project Sunshine for Japan. Posters, Stories and poems about Fukushima''' <ref>http://www.verlag-kettler.de/en/programm/project-sunshine-japan-posters-stories-and-poems-about-fukushima (Website Publisher Kettler. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> (published in March 2013) presents the award-winning posters and literary articles by authors from 15 countries in 13 languages. Participating authors are [[Yuri Andrukhovych]] (Ukraine), Rolf Bertram (Germany), Andrea Biscaro (Italy), Biyú Suárez Céspedes (Bolivia), Kevin Chen (Taiwan), Thomas Dersee (Germany), Anton Eisenhauer (Germany), Rainer Frentzel-Beyme (Germany), (Germany), [[Günter Grass]] (Germany), Angelica Guzmán (Bolivia), Günther Hager (Austria), Ohm Jung Ho (Korea), Taro Igarashi (Japan), Mustafa Ijaz (Turkey), Koji Ikeda (Japan), Tokiko Kiyota (Japan), Prof. Dr. Masayuki Komatsu (Japan), Wilfried Korfmacher (Japan), Josef Lutz (Germany), Michiko Mae (Germany/Japan), Sarita Mansilla (Bolivia), Stephan Moldzio (Germany), Shinji Nakagawa (Japan), Akmal Nasery Basral (Indonesia), Sixto Paz Wells (Peru), [[Peace Boat]] (Japan), Michael Pilath (Germany), Mansoureh Rahnama (Germany/Iran), Sapna Rangaswamy (India), Naemi Reymann (Germany), [[RICOH]] Deutschland GmbH (Germany), [[Ryuichi Sakamoto]] (Japan), Prima Santika (Indonesia), Elisabeth Scherer (Germany), Gert Scobel (Germany), Shinnoske Sugisaki (Japan), Shinpei Takeda (Japan), Dejan Vukelic (Serbia), Izumi Yamaguchi (Japan), [[Peter Zec]] (Germany), Dirk Zimmermann (Germany), and Rui Zink (Rui Zink). The German poster designer Uwe Loesch created the book cover and exhibition posters.<ref>http://en.red-dot.org/4522.html (red dot. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref>
== Exhibitions (selection) ==
*[[Fachhochschule Düsseldorf]] (University of Applied Science Düsseldorf) 2011 <ref>http://en.red-dot.org/4522.html (red dot design museum 20 April 2011. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref name=Reymann>{{cite book|title=Project Sunshine for Japan. Posters, Stories and poems about Fukushima by Mansoureh Rahnama|year=2013|publisher=Ketter|location=Lünen|page=12|isbn=978-3-86206-219-5|author=Naemi Reymann}}</ref><ref>http://www.rp-online.de/nrw/100-plakate-zu-fukushima-aid-1.2630910 (Rheinische Post, 7 Dec 2011. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.labkultur.tv/video/flagge-zeigen-fuer-japan-tohoku-erdbeben-tsunami-und-fukushima (Labkultur, 25 June 2011. Website in German. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.afdesta.ir/news/show/94{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (Afdesta, Iranian Design Institute 2 August 2011. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *Trade Fair Tokyo 2012 <ref name=Reymann/><ref>http://www.a1retailmagazine.com/latest-news/euroshop-and-japan-shop-present-project-sunshine-for-japan-in-tokyo/{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (A1 retail magazine; 7 June 2012. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.messe-dus.co.jp/fileadmin/newsletters/EuroRetailNEWS_2012.02.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222013100/http://www.messe-dus.co.jp/fileadmin/newsletters/EuroRetailNEWS_2012.02.pdf |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }} (EuroShop-Traid Fair 15 March 2012. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *Japanese Cultural Institute in Cologne 2012 <ref name=Reymann/><ref name="aaa.tu-dortmund.de">{{cite web |url=http://www.aaa.tu-dortmund.de/cms/de/Internationale_Studierende/Alumni_International/AluInt_Medienpool/NL_0413.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222031852/http://www.aaa.tu-dortmund.de/cms/de/Internationale_Studierende/Alumni_International/AluInt_Medienpool/NL_0413.pdf |archivedate=2014-02-22 |df= }} (Tu Dortmund Alumni page 6. Spring 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *ATC Gallery at The [[Osaka]] Design Center 2012 <ref name=Reymann/><ref name="aaa.tu-dortmund.de"/> *[[Peace Boat]] in [[Nagoya]] and [[Kobe]] Ports 2012 <ref name=Reymann/><ref name="aaa.tu-dortmund.de"/> *''Global Conference for a Nuclear Power Free World 2'' in [[Tokyo]] 2012 <ref name=Reymann/><ref name="aaa.tu-dortmund.de"/><ref>http://npfree.jp/english.html (Conference website. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *Kulturort Depot (Cultural Centre Depot) 2013 <ref name="aaa.tu-dortmund.de"/><ref>http://en.red-dot.org/5007.html (reddot design 15 February 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://myemail.constantcontact.com/OCAD-University-Alumni-Newsletter.html?soid=1101760402938&aid=cjumpPswv50 (OCAD Toronto Canada 2011. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *[[Frankfurt Book Fair]] October 13, 2013 <ref>https://en.book-fair.com/networking/search_find/companies/listEvent.aspx?PageRequestId=da894178-aeff-4760-a845-2bab0166aaa6&42abdb54-9d4d-4c94-a338-b0e96bcf9e73=08e41691-65af-4e7e-b51a-24091b63791f ([[Frankfurt Book Fair]] October 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://en.red-dot.org/5007.html (reddot design 15 Feb 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aD0pu5ckaEE (Youtube from 23 January 2014. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *House of Artists in Teheran 2013 <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icograda.org/news/year/2013_news/articles2477.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224104628/http://www.icograda.org/news/year/2013_news/articles2477.htm |archivedate=2014-02-24 |df= }} ([[Icograda]] IDA Canada May 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/arts-and-culture/106714-iran-to-enjoy-project-sunshine-for-japan |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130418043401/http://www.tehrantimes.com/arts-and-culture/106714-iran-to-enjoy-project-sunshine-for-japan |archivedate=2013-04-18 |df= }} (Tehran Times 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *Vesal e Shiraz in Souratgar Gallery in Shiraz 2013 <ref>http://newsite.graphiciran.com/Fa/News/News.aspx?nwsId=873 ([[Icograda]] IDA Canada 9 July 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref><ref>http://www.rangmagazine.com/?type=dynamic&lang=1&id=2822 (Shiraz-Rang Magazine Iran 10 July 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref> *Creative Network Center Mebic Ogimachi in [[Osaka]] 2014 <ref>http://www.mebic.com/event/4720.html ([[MEBIC]] Osaka 9 September 2014. Retrieved 14 October 2014)</ref><ref>http://gcgc.jp/event/project-sunshine-for-japan.html GCGC Creative news Osaka (GCGC 9 September 2014. Retrieved 14 October 2014)</ref>
== Publication ==
*Project Sunshine for Japan. Posters, Stories and poems about Fukushima, Editor Mansoureh Rahnama (D), Kettler, Lünen, 2013, {{ISBN|978-3-86206-219-5}} <ref>http://www.verlag-kettler.de/en/programm/project-sunshine-japan-posters-stories-and-poems-about-fukushima (Publisher Kettler. Retrieved 8 February 2014)</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links ==
*{{Official website|http://www.projectsunshineforjapan.wordpress.com}} *[http://en.red-dot.org/5007.html reddot design about the project] (15 February 2013. Retrieved 8 February 2014)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Project sunshine for japan}} [[Category:Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]] [[Category:Design awards]] [[Category:Poster artists]] [[Category:Social networks]]

{{Primary sources|date=December 2008}} {{Infobox Organization |image = RTC-symbol.png |size = 120px |caption = Logo of Religious Technology Center |name = Religious Technology Center |formation = 1982 |type = Religious / Commercial |status = Disputed (Various countries classify it as a business) |purpose = |headquarters = [[Hemet, California]], United States |leader_title = Chairman |leader_name = [[David Miscavige]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.rtc.org/ www.rtc.org] |remarks = }} The '''Religious Technology Center''' ('''RTC''') is an American [[non-profit corporation]][[commons:File:IRS-Recognition-Denmark.djvu|Letter by the Internal Revenue Service to Flemming Paludan, Regional Director, Danish Tax-Office, Washington, D.C., USA, December 22, 1993]]{{cite book|last=Rosenoer|first=Jonathan |title=Cyberlaw: the law of the Internet|publisher=Springer|year=1997|page=62|isbn=978-0-387-94832-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HlG2esMIm7kC&pg=PA62&dq=%22Religious+Technology+Center%22+%22non-profit%22&lr=#v=onepage&q=%22Religious%20Technology%20Center%22%20%22non-profit%22&f=false}} that was founded in 1982 by the [[Church of Scientology]] to control and oversee the use of all of the trademarks, symbols and texts of [[Scientology]] and [[Dianetics]]. Although RTC controls their use, those works are owned by another corporation, the [[Church of Spiritual Technology]] which is [[doing business as]] L. Ron Hubbard Library, registered in [[Los Angeles County]], California.[http://www.lavote.net/CLERK/FBN_Search.cfm Los Angeles County Registrar-Recorder/County Clerk, as an example] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070628174722/http://www.lavote.net/CLERK/FBN_Search.cfm |date=2007-06-28 }}, under "HUBBARD L RON LIBRARY"[http://www.scientology.org/csi.htm Notice for Materials Copyrighted to Church of Scientology International] While exercising authority over the use of all Dianetics and Scientology materials, RTC claims that it is not involved in the day-to-day management of the Church of Scientology; that role is assigned to a separate corporation, the [[Church of Scientology International]] (CSI). According to the RTC website, "RTC stands apart as an external body which protects the Scientology religion and acts as the final arbiter of orthodoxy" and its stated purpose is "to protect the public from misapplication of the technology and to see that the religious technologies of Dianetics and Scientology remain in proper hands and are properly ministered."[http://www.rtc.org/en_US/guarant/pg004.html Section of RTC Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430043739/http://www.rtc.org/en_US/guarant/pg004.html |date=2006-04-30 }} Since 1986, [[David Miscavige]] has served as the organization's Chairman of the Board.{{cite book |last = Lewis |first = James R. |authorlink = James R. Lewis (scholar) |title = Controversial New Religions |publisher = Oxford University Press |year = 2004 |isbn = 0-19-515683-8 |page= 247 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YCNd2YPFKTMC}} In a 1993 [[memorandum]] by the [[Church of Scientology International]], the following information was provided to the [[Internal Revenue Service]] with regards to RTC's role and functions, its personnel and its income:[[:File:Summary Description RTC-CSI.pdf|Summary Description of Churches of Scientology - RTC, CSI, CSFSSO, CSFSO, Other Churches, Missions, Field Ministers, CSI Prod. 11-4-93, Bate Stamp: 151396 - 151398, Ex. 1-3, Washington, DC, 1993]]
"[...] RTC [...] owns the Scientology religious marks and advanced technology. It licenses the marks to CSI for sublicense to subordinate churches and directly licenses the advanced technology to appropriate churches. Through this structure RTC assures that practice of the Scientology religion within the ecclesiastical hierarchy under CSI's authority as Mother Church remains strictly orthodox, in accordance with the Scientology Scriptures. This church has a staff of approximately 50 individuals and an annual budget of approximately $ 6.6 million, based on its annual disbursements for the most recent year for which financial statements are available. [...]"
The RTC guarantees the “purity and workability of Scientology so far into the future,” thus engaging in programs to “restore, preserve, maintain and keep uncorrupted” the church’s "religious technology," according to Scientology spokesman Eric Roux.{{cite news | title = Scientology faces ban in Belgium | url = http://www.news.com.au/world/europe/scientology-faces-ban-in-belgium-amid-fraud-allegations/news-story/c8433d3f797edff382cfd35608e09d2b | work = AFP | publisher = news.com.au | date = December 12, 2015 | accessdate = March 26, 2017}}{{cite book |last=Roux |first1=Eric |title=Cult Wars in Historical Perspective: New and Minority Religions |chapter=Scientology |editor-last=Gallagher |editor-first=Eugene V. |publisher=Routledge |date=21 July 2016 |isbn=978-1472458124 }} ==Corporate information== [[File:Church of Scientology building in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California.jpeg|thumb|Offices of the Religious Technology Center in Los Angeles]] RTC was [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] on January 1, 1982 in Los Angeles, California by Terri Gamboa, [[David Mayo (Scientology)|David Mayo]], Norman Starkey, Phoebe Mauerer, Lyman Spurlock, Julia Watson, and [[David Miscavige]].[[commons:File:RTC-Incorporation.djvu|Articles of Incorporation of Religious Technology Center, Endorsed Filed in the Office of the Secretary of State of the State of California, Los Angeles, California, January 1, 1982]] Six months later, on June 15, 1982, the [[Articles of Incorporation]] were restated.[[commons:File:RTC-Restated-Incorporation.djvu|Restated Articles of Incorporation of Religious Technology Center, Bate Stamp: A 253931, Los Angeles, California, June 15th & September 13th, 1982]] On April 8, 1986 they were amended in order to clarify the [[disposition]] of RTC's [[assets]] upon the [[dissolution (law)|dissolution]] of the [[corporation]].[[commons:File:RTC-Certificate-Amendment.djvu|Certificate of Amendment of Articles of Incorporation - Religious Technology Center, Los Angeles, California, April 8th, May 13th & 14th, 1986]] At present the official address of RTC is 1710 Ivar Avenue, Suite 1100, Los Angeles 90028, in the Hollywood Guaranty Building, while its main offices are on a big estate complex at 19625 Highway 79, Gilman Hot Springs 92383, California, as it was stated in a supporting document of Scientology's tax-exempt application to the IRS during the years 1992/1993.[[:File:Location-RTC.pdf|Response to Second Series of Questions, Church of Scientology International, Correspondence with Internal Revenue Service, Exhibit for Application for Tax-Exempt Status 501(c)(3), June 29th, 1992]] On September 21, 1993 the following individuals held [[corporate]] positions at RTC: The [[Board of Trustees]] was composed of [[David Miscavige]], Gregory Wilhere, and Norman F. Starkey. The members of RTC's [[Board of Directors]] were at that time [[Mark Rathbun]], Warren McShane, and [[David Miscavige]]. RTC's [[President (corporate title)|President]] was [[Mark Rathbun]], its [[Secretary]] Warren McShane, and its [[Treasurer]] Barbara Griffin.[[:File:CoS-Trustees-Directors-Officers-1993.pdf|List of Trustees, Directors & Officers (of Church of Scientology Entities) - Ex. I-2, CSI Prod 11-4-93, Bate Stamp: 151380 - 151395, Los Angeles, California, September 21st, 1993]] As of February 5, 2001 RTC's corporate [[board of directors|officers]] were Warren McShane ([[Chief Executive Officer]]/[[President (corporate title)|President]]), Laurisse Stuckenbrock ([[Secretary]]), and Barbara Griffin ([[Chief Financial Officer]]/[[Treasurer]]).Statement by Domestic Nonprofit Corporation, Religious Technology Center, Secretary of State, State of California, Filed: Sacramento, California, February 9th, 2001 As of March 14, 2008, RTC's official [[Agent (law)|agent]] has been the attorney Sherman D. Lenske from the law firm Lenske, Lenske & Abramson ALC, Warner Atrium, 6400 Canoga Avenue, Suite 315, Woodland Hills 91367-2491.[http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/corpdata/ShowAllList?QueryCorpNumber=C1063697 Entry for Religious Technology Center, California Business Portal of the Secretary of the State of California/March 22, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180322/http://kepler.sos.ca.gov/corpdata/ShowAllList?QueryCorpNumber=C1063697 |date=March 3, 2016 }} On August 19, 1993, RTC filed an application for [[tax exemption]] under section [[501(c)(3)]] of the [[Internal Revenue Code]].[[:File:Application-501-RTC.pdf|Form 1023 - Application for Recognition of Exemption Under Section 501 (c) (3) of the Internal Revenue Code - Religious Technology Center, Washington, DC, August 19th, 1993]] In the same year the [[Internal Revenue Service]] granted RTC's request for exemption. The granting of tax exemption to RTC and other Scientology corporations was preceded by years of continuous litigation between the IRS and the various entities of Scientology. According to former high-ranking executives, the Scientology organization had launched about 200 [[lawsuits]] against the IRS until 1991. During the same time, individual [[parish]]ioners of Scientology had initiated 2,300 [[Claim (legal)|claims]] against the agency, challenging the denial of tax deduction for their services at Scientology organizations. Late 1991, the dispute over Scientology's tax-exempt status began to resolve through high-level meetings between [[David Miscavige]] and the then [[Commissioner of Internal Revenue|Commissioner of the IRS]], Fred Goldberg, who encouraged a final resolution of the legal battle.[http://www.tampabay.com/news/article1012148.ece Scientology: The Truth Rundown, Part 1 of 3 in a special report on the Church of Scientology, By Joe Childs & Thomas C. Tobin, Saint Petersburg Times, 2009-06-21, retrieved on 2009-06-21] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209040134/http://www.tampabay.com/news/article1012148.ece |date=2013-02-09 }} '''Main Corporate Activities''' The Religious Technology Center (RTC) is the [[owner]] of certain [[trademarks]] and [[service marks]]. These marks and its related [[intellectual property]] form the "Dianetics spiritual healing technology" and the "Scientology applied religious technology".Copyright and trademark notice of the book "Dianetics" by L. Ron Hubbard, Los Angeles, California, (c) 1950, 2000, {{ISBN|0-88404-632-X}} Scientology organizations, like "Churches," "Celebrity Centres" or "Missions," derive their income from the worldwide sales of this "technology" in form of courses, books, etc. to their members or to the general public. The organizations receive the right to sell the "technology" through license agreements with RTC as license holder and/or the [[Church of Scientology International]] (CSI) as a sub-licensor. RTC and CSI in return derive their corporative income through the license fees, which in turn are obtained through those agreements. The licensing and its related actions are major corporate activities of the various Scientology-organizations.[[:File:License-Agreement-RTC-CSI.pdf|"License Agreement - CSI (Marks)", License Agreement between Religious Technology Center and Church of Scientology International, California, May 18th, 1982]] '''Licensing of Trademarks & Service Marks''' * ''Religious Technology Center (RTC) and [[Church of Spiritual Technology]] (CST)'' Shortly after its inception on January 1, 1982, RTC received on May 16, 1982 "the ownership, supervision and control" of the trademarks and service marks identifying "Scientology applied religious philosophy" and "Dianetics spiritual healing technology" by the originator and founder of Scientology, [[L. Ron Hubbard]] through an "[[Assignment (law)|Assignment]] [[Contract|Agreement]]".[[:File:Assignment-RTC.pdf|"Assignment Agreement (LRH/RTC) (Marks)", Notarized Agreement between L. Ron Hubbard and the Religious Technology Center, County of Los Angeles, California, May 16th, 1982]] This agreement was subject to an additional "Option Agreement" between Hubbard, RTC and another Scientology corporation, the "[[Church of Spiritual Technology]]" (CST). In two "Option Agreements" from May 1982, Hubbard granted CST the right to purchase at any time from RTC the "Marks", the "Advanced Technology" and all the rights to them for the sum of $100.[[:File:Option-Agreement-LRH-CST.pdf|"Option Agreement (Marks)", Notarized Agreement between L. Ron Hubbard and the Church of Spiritual Technology, County of Los Angeles, California, May 10th, 1982/July 9th, 1982]][[:File:Option-Agreement-LRH-CST-AT.pdf|Option Agreement (Advanced Technology-U.S.) - Notarized Agreement between L. Ron Hubbard and the Church of Spiritual Technology, California, May 10th & July 9th, 1982]] Parallel and similar-sounding agreements between Hubbard, RTC and CST were created during that period concerning the "Advanced Technology," which consists of unpublished derivates of Scientology's confidential "Advanced technology".[[:File:Assignment-Agreement-LRH-RTC-AT.pdf|"Assignment Agreement (LRH/RTC) (Advanced Technology - US)", Notarized Agreement between L. Ron Hubbard and the Religious Technology Center, Los Angeles, California, May 10th & 16th, 1982]] Under these agreements RTC is to turn over 90% of its net income to CST. A document from 1991, reflecting the "financial money flows" of RTC during the year 1989, showed a turnover of 59% of RTC's net income towards CST.[[:File:Analysis-Financial-Flows-RTC.pdf|"Religious Technology Center - Analysis of Financial Flows 1989", Exhibit I-9 for Application for Tax-Exempt Status 501(c)(3), Bate Stamp: CSI Prod 11-4-93 151414]] * ''Religious Technology Center (RTC) and [[Church of Scientology International]] (CSI)'' RTC and CSI entered a license agreement on May 18, 1982, granting CSI, the new "Mother Church of Scientology," the right to use and sub-license certain of the trademarks and service marks. In return for the grant of the marks, the agreement gave RTC practically an unlimited corporate control not only over the activities of CSI but also over every organization that is a sub-licensee of CSI. In particular the agreement stated:
"[...] d) RTC shall have the right to monitor all operations of CSI and its related organizations, inspect all books, records and facilities, pertaining to use of the Marks and receive sample specimens and summaries of literature, publications and products using the marks, [...] e) RTC may, if it ever deems it necessary or advisable, send a corrective mission to any organization authorized the Marks to correct any deviation from the standards, specifications or guidelines of this Agreement, [... ]"
Additionally RTC and CSI signed on January 1, 1982 an "Organizational Covenant" granting CSI the right to deliver the "Advanced Technology" to its staff members.[[:File:Covenant-RTC-CSI-AT.pdf|"Organizational Covenant - Advanced Technology - US", Covenant between Church of Scientology International & Religious Technology Center, Location: probably Los Angeles, California, January 1st, 1982]] * ''Religious Technology Center (RTC) and [[Church of Scientology Western United States]] (CoSWUS)'' RTC and CoSWUS entered on May 23, 1985 an organizational covenant granting CoSWUS the right to sell and deliver the "Advanced Technology" to its public members while guaranteeing weekly payments of 6% of the monetary value of the "Advanced Technology"-services that are being delivered to the public from CoSWUS towards RTC.[[:File:Covenant-RTC-CSWUS-AT.pdf|"Organizational Covenant - Advanced Technology - US", Covenant between the Church of Scientology Western United States & Religious Technology Center, Location: probably: Los Angeles, California, May 23rd, 1985]] * ''Religious Technology Center (RTC) and [[Church of Scientology Flag Service Organization, Inc.]] (FSO)'' On January 1, 1982 RTC and FSO signed an organizational covenant with similar content to the covenant between RTC and CoSWUS.[[:File:Covenant-RTC-CSFSO-AT.pdf|"Organizational Covenant - Advanced Technology - US", Covenant between Church of Scientology Flag Service Organization & Religious Technology Center, Location: probably Clearwater, Florida, January 1st, 1982]] * ''Religious Technology Center (RTC) and other Scientology organizations'' RTC has entered over the years similar organizational covenants/license agreements with all the other "Advanced Organizations" (AOs) within the Scientology network. As all the AO's are integrated within a corporation, these agreements are formulated between RTC and these corporations, such as "Church of Scientology Flag Ship Service Organization, Inc." from Netherlands Antilles,[[:File:License-Agreement-RTC-FSSO.pdf|License Agreement - RTC/Licensee - License Agreement between Religious Technology Center and Church of Scientology Flag Ship Service Organization, Netherlands Antilles, June 2nd, 1988]] the "Church of Scientology Religious Education College, Inc." from East Grinstead, England,[[:File:Covenant-RTC-CoSRECI-AT.pdf|Advanced Technology Covenant RTC/RECI, Covenant between Religious Technology Center & Church of Scientology Religious Education College, Inc., East Grinstead, England, November 18th, & December 1st, 1988]] the "Church of Scientology, Inc." from Sydney, Australia[[:File:Covenant-RTC-CoSInc-AT.pdf|Advanced Technology Covenant RTC/Church of Scientology (Australia), Covenant between Religious Technology Center & Church of Scientology Inc., Sydney, Australia, December 24th, 1988 & March 16th, 1989]] and with "Church of Scientology Advanced Organization Saint Hill Europe & Africa" (AOSH EU).[[:File:Covenant-RTC-AOSHEU-AT.pdf|Example Covenant: "Advanced Technology Covenant - RTC/AOSH", Covenant between the Church of Scientology Advanced Organization Saint Hill Europe & Africa & Religious Technology Center, Copenhagen, Denmark, December 1st, 1988, November 25th & December 14th, 1989]] RTC has registered its service marks and trademarks in various countries all over the world. Due to certain legal restrictions for religious corporations in certain countries, RTC founded the corporation "Inspector General Network, Inc." (IGN) on June 7, 1985, which functions as a "secular" representative for RTC in those countries.[[:File:Amendement-Incorporation-IGN.pdf|Notarized Certificate of Amendment of Articles of Incorporation, Inspector General Network, Endorsed Filed in the Office of the Secretary of State in the State of California, CSI Prod - November 22, 1993 - Bate Stamp: 237255, Los Angeles, California, June 7th, 1985]] In 1985 RTC entered with IGN a so-called "Reversion and Reservation Agreement", which regulated the rights and obligations with regards to the Scientology and Dianetics trademarks of the "secular" organizations IGN and "World Institute of Scientology Enterprises, Inc." (WISE Inc.), a dormant Delaware corporation.[[:File:Reversion-Agreement-RTC-WISE.pdf|Reversion and Reservation Agreement between Religious Technology Center and Inspector General Network, a California non-profit public benefit corporation, Los Angeles, California, June 17th, & 18th, 1985]] '''Control of Other Corporations''' At the time of RTC's filing for [[tax exemption]], RTC controlled four other corporations: * ''"Inspector General Network" (IGN)'' IGN has served as [[legal]] [[agent (law)|representative]] for RTC and [[secular]] [[registered owner]] of RTC's [[trademarks|trade]] and [[service marks]] "in countries where contracts by religious corporations are not enforced". All [[corporate]] positions of IGN were held by members of RTC. * ''"WISE, Inc."'' At the time of [[Scientology|Scientology's]] application for [[tax exemption]], WISE, Inc. has been a dormant [[corporation]] from [[Delaware]]. It had the same functions as IGN, prior to IGN's [[Incorporation (business)|incorporation]] in 1985. * ''"RTC Australia"'' RTC Australia was [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] in 1986 as a regional office for RTC in Australia. It is a dormant [[corporation]] and has obtained [[tax exempt]] status. * ''"Inspector General Network International AB" (IGN Int)'' IGN was [[Incorporation (business)|incorporated]] in 1992 in Sweden. The organization was founded to [[Registered trademark symbol|register]] [[Scientology|Scientology's]] [[trademarks|trade]] and [[service marks]] as a [[nominee]] for RTC in [[countries]], such as [[Libya]] or [[Iran]] "that do not recognize and will not do business with any United States entity". ==Organizational structure and management== RTC stands hierarchically at the top of the [[Church of Scientology]] network. It has regulatory, corporate and [[ecclesiastical]] power over the policy and activities of all other Scientology management units, corporations, churches, missions and other organizations - with the only exception being the [[Church of Spiritual Technology]]. The position of RTC is notably visible in a drawing titled "The Command Channels of Scientology", which the [[Church of Scientology International]] (CSI) and RTC provided to the IRS in their application for tax-exempt status. It should be noted that the [[Church of Spiritual Technology]] has not been included in this application.[[commons:Image:Command Channels CoS.jpg|The Command Channels of Scientology, Sketch depicting the hierarchical structure of the network of the Church of Scientology, the drawing was provided by CSI to the IRS in their application for tax-exempt status in September 1993]] In its application for tax exemption, RTC described the internal structure of the organization as follows:
"[...] RTC's daily activities are carried out by a staff of 54 highly-trained individuals who function in their positions within the overall ecclesiastical hierarchy of the Scientology religion. Through receipt of reports and direct inspections, RTC ensures that those utilizing the marks are ministering orthodox Scientology religious services. [...]"
"[...] The senior ecclesiastical position in RTC is held by David Miscavige, who continues to serve as Chairman of the Board RTC and also as Inspector General. There are also several Deputy Inspector Generals who assist in the performance of RTC's religious functions. There is a Deputy Inspector General who functions as Chairman of the Board RTC's second in command and sees to the day to day functioning of the organization. There is a Deputy Inspector General who oversees internal matters in RTC and another who is in charge of RTC's religious programs."
"The religious mission of RTC, protecting the orthodoxy of the technologies of Dianetics and Scientology, is carried out by two ecclesiastical divisions within RTC as described below. There is now one Inspectorate division which consists of four departments. The Department of Data receives reports and collects information from other organizations and Scientologists and collates, analyzes and distributes the information to all other departments that require it.
"The Department of Trademark Registration, Maintenance and Enforcement gets the religious marks of Dianetics and Scientology legally registered and sees to it that all users of the marks are properly licensed. It also investigates and, where necessary, prosecutes legal infringements of the marks."
"The Department of Technical Policing inspects application of the Scientology Scriptures pertaining to the ministry of religious services by licensees and corrects misapplication where it is found."
"The Department of Organization Policing inspects the application of Scientology Scriptures as it pertains to governance of the ecclesiastical hierarchy and corrects misapplication where it is found."
"Authorization, Verification and Correction International ('AVC INT') is a division within RTC which is responsible for authorizing and verifying that the ecclesiastical programs, evaluations, strategies, promotional materials and issues as authored by CSI are in accordance with Scripture. [...]"
As previously mentioned, RTC is currently led by the "[[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]] (of [[Board of directors|Directors]])" [[David Miscavige]], who has held this position since 1987. Miscavige has been in leading positions within the Scientology management since the early 1980s. Prior to being in his current position, Miscavige had been a member of the [[Commodore's Messenger Organization]] and had been instrumental in the internal purge of the [[Guardian's Office]], the former [[intelligence service]] and legal defense unit of the Scientology network. In 1982 he became the [[Chief Executive Officer]] and later the [[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]] of the [[for-profit corporation]] [[Author Services Inc.]] (ASI). Miscavige stayed on this position until 1987.[http://www.culteducation.com/reference/scientology/Scien56.html The Man behind Scientology by Thomas C. Tobin, St. Petersburg Times, October 25, 1998] About the role and the position of the RTC within the structure of the Scientology network, David Miscavige declared in 1994:[[:File:Declaration David Miscavige 1994.pdf|Declaration of David Miscavige, Church of Scientology International vs. Steven Fishman & Uwe Geertz, Case No. CV 91-6426 (HLH (Tx), U.S. District Court for the Central District of California, Riverside County, February 8th, 1994]]
"[...] Since March of 1987, I have been Chairman of the Board of Religious Technology Center [...]. RTC is not part of Church management, nor is it involved in the daily affairs of various Church of Scientology organizations or missions. RTC ensures that the trademarks of Dianetics and Scientology, and the technology they represent, are properly used around the world.
[...] 8 . RTC was formed with the specific purpose of seeing that the religion of Scientology was kept pure and true to the source materials of the religion. In fact, a major reason for its formation was to have such a Church organization that performed these functions in a capacity entirely separate from the actual management of the various Churches and Missions of Scientology. Not only is RTC not involved in the management of the international hierarchy of Scientology churches, but its very existence and performance of its true functions depends on the fact that it is not part of Church management. The authority of the Religious Technology Center stems from the ownership of the trademarks of Dianetics and Scientology.
[...] 11. Neither RTC nor I has any corporate authority over any Scientology church, including CSI. CSI is the Mother Church of the Scientology religion and has been since its inception in 1981. As such, CSI is responsible for the activities commensurate with such a role, including the ecclesiastical management of Churches, dissemination and propagation of the faith and defense of its activities, including external and legal affairs. [...]"
Such representations stand in stark contrast to declarations of high-level ex-scientologists, who have worked in the Scientology management. Former CSI security officer Andre Tabayoyon and former RTC second-in-command Jesse Prince have stated in [[affidavit]]s and declarations that RTC and its chairman [[David Miscavige]] maintain de facto control of the entire Scientology network, including the [[Church of Scientology International]].[http://lisatrust.bogie.nl/Media/video/legal/prince_erlich.pdf Affidavit of Jesse Prince] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041101175401/http://lisatrust.bogie.nl/Media/video/legal/prince_erlich.pdf |date=2004-11-01 }} United States District Court, Central District of California, San Jose Division case no. C-95-20091 RMW (EAI) Within that context, André Tabayoyon stated in a 1994 declaration the following about Miscavige's exertion of power as [[Chair (official)|Chairman of the Board]] and ultimate [[head]] of the global [[Scientology]] network:[http://www.whyaretheydead.net/krasel/aff_at.html Declaration of Andre Tabayoyon from April 4, 1994, Church of Scientology International, Case No. CV 91 6426 HLH (Tx), U.S. District Court for the Central District of California] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926224143/http://www.whyaretheydead.net/krasel/aff_at.html |date=September 26, 2007 }}
"[...] 59. I have personal knowledge that Miscavige issues oral and written orders and instructions to Scientologists irrespective of either ecclesiastical lines of authority or corporate lines of is authority or demarcation. Miscavige uses this omnipotent authority to exercise personal control over any and all Scientology organizations whenever he elects to do so. I observed that in running the various Scientology organizations, Miscavige constantly crosses all corporate and ecclesiastical command lines without regard to the fact that there are numerous Scientology related corporations of which he is neither an employee, officer nor director. He does not have to be to control any Scientology organization. He is above all Scientology organizations as the ecclesiastical head of Scientology, COB RTC and Commander of the Sea Org. In this capacity, Miscavige acts as the managing agent of each Scientology organization."
"[...] 61. I personally observed Miscavige take over this position of ultimate power over all of Scientology after Hubbard died. I observed Miscavige when he was COB RTC ordering into Golden Era Studios ("Gold"), a CSI division, and ordering into the Commodore's Messenger Organization International ("CMO Int"), another CSI division planetary dissemination organization, etc. Both of these Sea Org units are corporately part of CSI. RTC, CMO Int and Gold are all located at a large compound outside of Hemet, California. It is called Gold. As I learned, the Scientology corporate structure was only for the benefit of the outside "wog" world. It didn't have any bearing on how Scientology operated."
"62. When Hubbard was alive it was common knowledge and I also observed it personally that he was in direct control, via Miscavige and [[Pat Broeker]], of CMO Int and Gold, and the rest of Scientology. After Hubbard died[,] Miscavige ousted Pat Broeker and Vicki Aznaran, who were then in control of Scientology. After that, it was my experience that Miscavige had complete control over Scientology just as Hubbard had when he was alive. Miscavige took over Hubbard's place as managing agent of all Scientology organizations. [...]"
[[Mark Rathbun|Mark ("Marty") Rathbun]], [[David Miscavige]] and [[Warren McShane]], Deputy Inspector General for Legal Affairs formed for several years the above-mentioned "Board of Directors RTC".Religious Technology Center, Board of Directors, (c) 1999–2001 Religious Technology Center, http://www.rtc.org/board/ As of March 2008, all references to both Rathbun and McShane have disappeared from the RTC website, and their names or pictures have also been removed from other official Scientology websites. Though Miscavige is still listed as Chairman of the Board, no other board members are acknowledged.[http://www.rtc.org/david-miscavige.html David Miscavige - Official website of Religious Technology Center, (c) 1996–2008 Religious Technology Center] Within the executive branch of RTC existed at least until 2001 the position of "Inspector General RTC," which had been held by Mark Rathbun. This network spanned from RTC headquarters in Gilman Hot Springs to all of the "Advanced Organizations" in Los Angeles, Clearwater, East Grinstead, Copenhagen and Sidney, where RTC has maintained offices. In an internal newsletter, "Keeping Scientology Working," RTC stated the following about the purpose and duties of the "Inspector General Network":"Keeping Scientology Working", Caption of photo depicting the staff of the RTC IG Network, page 4, (c) 1995 Church of Scientology International
"These Deputy Inspector Generals head the entire IG Network, which locates and handles internal and external infiltration and suppression, legally protects and safeguards the trademarks and technology of the religion of Scientology, and sees that management, orgs and missions and their application of tech and policy remain standard and true to LRH's writings."
While RTC has a dominant role over the "mother church," CSI and its subordinate organizations, the relationship to the [[Church of Spiritual Technology]] (CST) is unclear. While the above-mentioned "assignment agreement" with L. Ron Hubbard on May 10, 1982 granted CST corporative authority over RTC with respect to Scientology's trademarks and service marks, there is no sign that CST ever executed any internal, "ecclesiastical" authority over RTC. In fact, the U.S. Claims Court noted in its opinion in a tax case, which involved CST in 1992:[http://www.angelfire.com/blog/suleiman2/cst_vs_irs_1992.html Opinion, Church of Spiritual Technology vs. United States, No. 581-88T, United Claims Court, June 29, 1992]
"CST claims that it does not and will not monitor RTC's use of the religious marks and technology. CST explains that there is no need to do so because any unorthodox use would be immediately obvious. Regardless of how it arrived at the conclusion, however, the point is that one of its obligations is to prevent misuse of the marks and technology. CST's present confidence in RTC has no significance. If CST ignored that element of its charter, one of the assumptions built into LRH's gift would be missing. Monitoring for a misuse by RTC is a form of ongoing oversight. The decision to exercise the option is an ecclesiastical one which would not be readily susceptible to judicial review."
==Litigation== Since its inception in 1982, RTC has been involved in various [[lawsuit]]s in both [[State court (United States)|state]] and [[United States federal courts|federal courts]]. The majority of the cases initiated by RTC contend unauthorized use of Scientology's [[copyright]]s, [[service mark]]s, or [[trademark]]s. Critics of Scientology contend that a great number of these lawsuits have been launched in order "to silence critics."Church in Cyberspace, Marc Fisher, Washington Post, August 19, 1995 The courts have agreed in some cases; in ''RTC v. Lerma'' Judge Leonie Brinkema found that the RTC's lawsuit was intended to pursue the "broader motivation" of "the stifling of criticism and dissent of the religious practices of Scientology and the destruction of its opponents."http://www.bostonphoenix.com/alt1/archive/specials/scientology/SCIENTOLOGY_1.html The RTC filed a lawsuit on January 1, 1985 in the [[United States District Court for the Central District of California]] against Robin Scott and the Church of New Civilization (not to be confused with the [[New Civilization Church]]), a Scientology splinter group, alleging [[theft]] and unauthorized use of confidential material owned by RTC. The case took over a decade to resolve, and was dismissed on April 11, 1996 by the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]]. In its final [[legal opinion|opinion]] the court summarized the history of the case and commented on the conduct of RTC while the case was litigated:[[s:Religious Technology Center v. Scott|Unpublished Opinion from April 11, 1996, Religious Technology Center et al. vs. Robin Scott et al., 82 F.3d 423, 1996 WL 171443, United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]]
"[...] In January 1985 RTC sued Mayo and other persons connected with the Church of the New Civilization, a splinter group of the official Church of Scientology, contending that they were making unauthorized use of stolen documents relating to the religion of Scientology. RTC stated that it was "the protector" of the religion of Scientology, its philosophy and its technology "including the Advanced Technology" consisting of "confidential and proprietary information regarding counseling and training," and was the owner of various trademarks registered with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] protecting the Advanced Technology. [...]"
"[...] After 1,825 docket entries and nine years of pretrial litigation involving three [[Discovery (law)|discovery]] [[United States magistrate judge|magistrates]], a special master, the [[recusal]] of two district court judges, the denial of five petitions for writ of [[mandamus]], three appeals [...] and three denials of [[certiorari]] by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]], the third district judge [...] entered Final Judgment."
"[...] [T]here is little doubt that RTC is playing "fast and loose" with the judicial system as required in the minority view of [[estoppel]]. To first assert that its unfair competition and false designation of origin claims are [[Justiciability|justiciable]] and at the same time assert that Mayo's identical claims are not is at best questionable; in light of RTC's documented history of [[Vexatious litigation|vexatious behavior]], RTC's actions are indefensible. [...]"
==Knowledge reports== The RTC maintains a task force called the Inspector General Network, an investigatory body which operates from seven offices on four different continents.{{cite web |url=http://www.rtc.org/en_US/guarant/pg004.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-04-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430043739/http://www.rtc.org/en_US/guarant/pg004.html |archivedate=2006-04-30 |df= }} The IGN's stated function is to "keep Scientology working by ensuring the pure and ethical use of Dianetics and Scientology technology."{{cite web |url=http://www.rtc.org/en_US/matters/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-10-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061022163614/http://www.rtc.org/en_US/matters/index.html |archivedate=2006-10-22 |df= }} RTC, like the Church of Scientology, encourages the use of "Knowledge Reports" (KR) from anyone inside or outside of the Church, to report on potential misuse of the [[Standard Tech]] and copyrighted/trademarked materials. They maintain an online form in which anyone is encouraged to report any such matters that may be of concern.https://www.rtc.org/reports/form/index.html?locale=en The use of reports is one system used by RTC to police the use of Scientology materials and the application. ==See also== {{Portal|Scientology}} *[[Author Services Inc.]] *[[Church of Spiritual Technology]] *[[Sea Org]] *[[List of Scientology organizations]] *[[Norton S. Karno]], an attorney for the Church of Scientology and for L. Ron Hubbard ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== '''Scientology sources''' *[http://www.rtc.org/ Official website of the Religious Technology Center] **[http://davidmiscavige.rtc.org/ Chairman of the Board, RTC] *[http://faq.scientology.org/page18a.htm Scientology FAQs: What is Religious Technology Center?] *[http://www.theta.com/goodman/rtc.htm A Description of the Religious Technology Center (RTC)] '''Critical sources''' * [http://www.lermanet.com/jesseprince.htm Jesse Prince articles] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060903153518/http://holysmoke.org/minton/mintonbf.htm Jesse Prince affidavit] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060525015029/http://planetkc.com/sloth/sci/mayo.html David Mayo affidavit] '''Magazine Articles''' * [https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/9363363/inside_scientology/print "Inside Scientology" by Janet Reitman, Rolling Stone Magazine, February 23, 2006] *[http://www.xenu.net/archive/go/quill.htm "Scientology from inside out" by Robert Vaughn Young, Quill magazine, Volume 81, Number 9, Nov/Dec 1993]. '''Diverse Sources''' *[https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=33.830819,-116.985984&spn=0.016425,0.027968&t=k&hl=en Satellite photograph of "Gold base," Gilman Hot Springs, California] {{Scientology}} [[Category:1982 establishments in California]] [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Scientology organizations]] [[Category:Hemet, California]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1982]] [[Category:Religious corporations]] [[Category:Organizations in Riverside County, California]]

{{Infobox award | name = Roux Scholarship | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = To find new talent in the catering industry. | presenter = [[Alain Roux]] and [[Michel Roux Jr]] | sponsor = | host = | date = | location = | country = United Kingdom | reward = Three months at a three [[Michelin star]] restaurant | year = 1984 | year2 = 2018 | holder = | website = [http://www.rouxscholarship.co.uk/index.php Official website] | network = [[Good Food]] (2012)
[[Watch (TV channel)|Watch]] (2013) }} '''The Roux Scholarship''' is a cooking competition for up and coming chefs in the UK. Set up by the brothers [[Michel Roux|Michel]] and [[Albert Roux]], and now run by their sons [[Alain Roux]] and [[Michel Roux Jr.|Michel Roux Jr]]. It was first run in 1984 with [[Andrew Fairlie (chef)|Andrew Fairlie]] being named the first winner. It has since been run on a yearly basis, with winners going on to win a three-month placement in a [[Michelin star]]red restaurants including the [[French Laundry]] and [[Maison Pic]]. ==History== [[Michel Roux]] credits Nick Rowe with originating the idea for the Roux Scholarship. Rowe was dining at Roux's [[Waterside Inn]] when he suggested to Roux that the Roux brothers could front a scholarship for up and coming chefs and that Rowe's credit card company would be willing to back it financially. Michel spoke to his brother [[Albert Roux|Albert]] the following day, who said that Michel could lead on it. Michel thought it would be a good way for young chefs to gain experience in French restaurants, which were not open to employing British chefs at the time.{{cite news|title=Michel Roux: The Roux Scholarship|url=http://www.tvchoicemagazine.co.uk/interviewextra/michel-roux-roux-scholarship|accessdate=3 September 2012|newspaper=TV Choice|date=10 July 2012}} The competition was formerly known as the Roux Diners Club Scholarship.{{cite news|title=Chris Colmer wins Roux Diners Club Scholarship|url=http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/30/01/2008/26826/chris-colmer-wins-roux-diners-club-scholarship.htm|accessdate=3 September 2012|newspaper=Caterer and Hotelkeeper|date=30 March 1995}} Each entrant must enter a paper application, which are then reviewed and broken down into regional competitions. Each regional winner goes through to the final, where there is one Scholar named.{{cite news|last=Kühn|first=Kerstin|title=Adam Smith named 2012 Roux Scholar|url=http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/22/06/2012/343465/Adam-Smith-named-2012-Roux-Scholar.htm|accessdate=3 September 2012|newspaper=Caterer and Hotelkeeper|date=27 April 2012}} Entrants are limited to chefs who are working in full-time employment.{{cite news|last=Kühn|first=Kerstin|title=One week left to enter the 2012 Roux Scholarship|url=http://www.caterersearch.com/Articles/23/01/2012/341988/One-week-left-to-enter-the-2012-Roux-Scholarship.htm|accessdate=3 September 2012|newspaper=Caterer and Hotelkeeper|date=23 January 2012}} Chefs are not limited to applying on one occasion; both [[Simon Hulstone]] and [[Mark Birchall]] competed on four occasions before winning. The winner of the competition is allowed to choose a three [[Michelin star]]red restaurant to cook in for three months.{{cite web|title = The Roux Scholarship|url = http://goodfood.uktv.co.uk/the-roux-masterclass/video/angela-hartnett-cooks-stone-bass-and-squid/|publisher = Good Food|accessdate = 3 September 2012}} The judges for the 2018 competition were [[Michel Roux, Jr.|Michel Jr.]], and [[Alain Roux]], alongside [[Brian Turner (chef)|Brian Turner]], [[James Martin (chef)|James Martin]] and Roux Scholars [[Andrew Fairlie (chef)|Andrew Fairlie,]] [[Sat Bains]], [https://www.clivedenhouse.co.uk/dine-with-us/andré-garrett-restaurant/ André Garrett], [https://www.elephantrestaurant.co.uk Simon Hulstone], as well as chefs [[Clare Smyth]], [[Angela Hartnett]] and [http://www.le-gavroche.co.uk Rachel Humphrey]. The Honorary President of Judges for the 2018 competition was [[Michel Guérard]]. The winner of the 2018 competition was Martin Carabott, who had previously competed in the national final twice and works for [http://www.hide.co.uk/ollie Ollie Dabbous] at Hide in London. ==Past winners== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Winner{{cite web|title=Past Winners|url=http://www.rouxscholarship.co.uk/roux_scholarship_winners.php|publisher=The Roux Scholarship|accessdate=3 September 2012}} ! Restaurant chosen ! Guy|url=http://www.rouxscholarship.co.uk/page/2016-harry-guy/|publisher=The Roux Scholarship|accessdate=19 February 2017}} |- | 2015 | {{sortname|Ian|Scaramuzza|dab=chef}} | [[Benu]] |{{cite revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox toy | name = Shopkins | image = File:Shopkins logo.png | caption = Current logo for Shopkins | type = Figures | materials = Plastic | inventor = Paul Salomon | country = [[Australia]] | company = [[Moose Toys]] | from = 2014
| website = www.shopkinsworld.com | slogan = "Once you shop... you can't stop!" }} '''Shopkins''' are a range of tiny, collectable toys, manufactured by [[Moose Toys]]. Based on [[grocery store]] items, each plastic figure has a recognisable face and unique name. They also have special finishes like translucent, glitter, or squishy. The collectable toys (which are designated as common, rare, ultra rare, special edition, limited edition, and exclusive) also have lines of clothing, trading cards, and other merchandise.
The toy line began in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web |title=Shopkins™ Is The Biggest Tiny Toy Crossing Retail Registers, With Season Two Characters To Continue Sales Momentum |url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/shopkins-is-the-biggest-tiny-toy-crossing-retail-registers-with-season-two-characters-to-continue-sales-momentum-300000580.html |website=PR Newswire |accessdate=23 June 2018 |date=24 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="toynews-online.biz">{{cite web|url=http://www.toynews-online.biz/news/read/2015-to-be-a-strong-year-for-shopkins/043431|title=2015 to be a strong year for Shopkins|publisher=}}</ref> As of the fall of 2018, there are ten seasons of the toys.
==History== Shopkins was designed and developed by [[Moose Toys]] in [[Melbourne]]. Co-chief Paul Solomon credits his mother Jacqui Tobias, director of girls’ products, for the idea of Shopkins.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/shopkins-inventor-among-toy-nominees|title=Shopkins Inventor Among Toy Nominees|publisher=}}</ref> Moose Toys had success with their line of [[Trash Pack]] and [[Grossery Gang]] collectible figurines which were geared towards boys, but overall lacked a market for girls. Shopkins was produced initially as a similar product for girls — however, it appeals to both genders.<ref name="racked.com">{{cite web|last=Nechamkin |first=Sarah |url=http://www.racked.com/2015/9/22/9365361/shopkins-tiny-toy-for-girls-consumerism-pink |title=How Shopkins Became the Biggest Tiny Toy on the Planet |publisher=Racked |date=2015-09-22 |accessdate=2017-07-10}}</ref><ref name="thestar.com">{{cite web|author=Cam Lindsay |url=https://www.thestar.com/life/2015/08/27/shopkins-the-latest-toy-craze-to-captivate-canadian-kids.html |title=Shopkins the latest toy craze to captivate Canadian kids | Toronto Star |publisher=Thestar.com |date=2015-08-27 |accessdate=2017-07-10}}</ref>
==Shopkins universe==
===Characters=== [[File:Shopkins Products.jpg|thumb|Shopkins products]]Shopkins figurines are roughly 1 inch in height and 1/2 inch in width, roughly the size of a United States Quarter. Each figurine has a face, name, and its own personality. They are distributed in bright coloured packaging with bubble letters.<ref name="winnipegfreepress.com">{{cite web|last=Lebar |first=Erin |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/arts-and-life/life/363151141.html |title=Girls (and parents) snapping up Shopkins, the latest collectible trend |publisher=Winnipeg Free Press |date= |accessdate=2017-07-10}}</ref> Shopkins are based on grocery items such as a sweet [[apple]] named Apple Blossom, a [[chocolate bar]] named Cheeky Chocolate, a [[lipstick]] named Lippy Lips, and a [[chocolate chip cookie]] named Kooky Cookie.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/christmas-2014-best-toys-and-gifts-for-boys-and-girls/news-story/812fe3ce4dd60067d997ae6055d04252?nk=b462cbab64d8b91c193f6cb4e0689794-1529619156 | title=Christmas 2014: Best toys and gifts for boys and girls|first=Chad |last=Van Estrop|newspaper=Herald Sun|date=15 November 2014|accessdate=21 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20140731005182/en/Moose-Toys%E2%84%A2-Live-Pets%E2%84%A2-Birds-Sound-Real|title=Moose Toys™ New Little Live Pets™ Birds Look and Sound Like a Real Pet Bird - Business Wire|date=31 July 2014|publisher=}}</ref> There are hundreds of Shopkins in the Shopkins World.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Many Shopkins are there total|author=Jill Thompson|url=http://spkfans.com/how-many-shopkins-are-there-total|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref> Shopkins are organized into categories such as Sweets or Bakery. Shopkins are collected and valued based on their rarity. Moose toys classifies the Shopkins degrees of rarity as Common, Exclusive, Limited Edition, Rare, Special Edition, and Ultra Rare.<ref>{{cite web|title=ShopkinsWorld.com|url=http://ShopkinsWorld.com|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref>
===Books=== Moose Toys launched a series of children's books about Shopkins including Scholastic's ''Shopkins: Welcome to Shopville''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/p/shopkins-jenne-simon/1123116997/2672224842575?st=PLA&sid=BNB_DRS_Marketplace+Shopping+Paperbackshopus_00000000&2sid=Google_&sourceId=PLGoP23146&k_clickid=3x23146|title=Shopkins: Welcome to Shopville|author=Barnes & Noble|work=Barnes & Noble}}</ref>
===Collector cards=== Moose Toys released their first [[trading card]] set in 2015.
===Shopkins movies=== An animated film called ''Shopkins: Chef Club'' was released on DVD 25 October 2016 by [[Universal Pictures Home Entertainment]] to promote the sixth season of Shopkins toys. The movie had mostly positive reviews, although some reviewers had concerns at the overt consumerism.<ref>{{cite web|title=Shopkins Chef Club Movie Reviews|author=Jill Thompson|url=http://spkfans.com/shopkins-chef-club-movie-reviews|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref>
Two sequels, Shopkins World Vacation and Shopkins Wild, were released on October 11, 2017 and April 17, 2018.
====Web series==== {{main article|List of Shopkins episodes}} In August 2014, Moose Toys built brand awareness with their Shopkins short cartoon videos on their YouTube channel Shopkins world,<ref name="racked.com"/> but it was the YouTube videos of consumers unwrapping and playing with the toy that helped bring the line to mainstream prominence.<ref name="moosetoys">{{cite web|url = http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/shopkins-is-the-biggest-tiny-toy-crossing-retail-registers-with-season-two-characters-to-continue-sales-momentum-300000580.html|title = Shopkins™ Is The Biggest Tiny Toy Crossing Retail Registers, With Season Two... -- LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24, 2014 /PRNewswire/ --|author = Moose Toys|date = 24 November 2014|publisher = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kentucky.com/news/business/article50009520.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223235942/http://www.kentucky.com/news/business/article50009520.html |archivedate=23 December 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Shopkins Direct === As of May 2017, [http://www.culturefly.com CultureFly LLC]., a licensee of Shopkins/Moose Toys, began offering a subscription box with exclusive Shopkins accessories and merchandise.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.streetinsider.com/Press+Releases/CultureFly+Announces+Shopkins+Direct/12871903.html|title=CultureFly Announces Shopkins Direct|work=StreetInsider.com|access-date=2017-07-22}}</ref> [http://www.shopkinsdirect.com/ Shopkins Direct] is described as a quarterly/seasonal subscription service, featuring accessories, apparel, and other exclusive merchandise featuring Shopkins characters. Additionally, exclusive Shopkins have been distributed via Shopkin pop-up chain stores located in North America. Such contents include but are not limited to: plushies, lip balm, and limited-edition Shopkins.
In March 2018, the box was discontinued.
==Counterfeit Shopkins== [[File:Shopkins Funny Sweet.jpg|thumbnail|Counterfeit Shopkins in packaging with "Funny Sweet" categories.]] [[Counterfeit consumer goods|Counterfeit]] Shopkins began to surface around mid-2015, including those with "Funny Sweet" or "Shopkinsins" on the packaging, which can refer to Shopkins in colours which Moose Toys never officially produced, such as ''Boo Hoo Onion'' being in light blue and ''Chee Zee'' in orange. The arms and other parts might be broken, and the paint chips off easily. <ref name="moosefake">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oRd4w_OQ8EE|title=The Official guide to spotting counterfeit Shopkins - YouTube|author=Moose Toys|date=12 August 2015|work=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref> A number of sellers on websites offer counterfeit Shopkins, which can include item pictures which have the "Shopkins" branding, most likely as a way to avoid the listing being taken away under [[intellectual property]] policies of the website and/or store.
===Cases=== Two factories in [[Yiwu]] producing counterfeit Shopkins toys were raided by local police in [[China]] in mid-2015,<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/police-raid-chinese-toy-factory-moose-enterprise-and-local-police-seize-over-150000-counterfeit-shopkins-toys-in-china-300121778.html "Police Raid Chinese Toy Factory: Moose Enterprise and Local Police Seize Over 150,000 Counterfeit Shopkins Toys in China,"] PR Newswire, 31 July 2015.</ref> and Moose Toys stated they will take legal action against anyone selling counterfeit Shopkins,<ref>[http://www.theabcshow.myindustrytracker.com/en/article/75292/anb-media-news-august-25?referer=read-next "Moose Continues to Defend Against Counterfeit Shopkins,"] ''aNB Media News'', August 25, 2015, Retrieved 16 January 2016</ref> which included a chain of Thriftway businesses selling counterfeit Shopkins.<ref>[http://www.leagle.com/decision/In%20FDCO%2020150813B45/MOOSE%20TOYS%20PTY%20LTD%20v.%20THRIFTWAY%20HYLAN%20BLVD.%20DRUG%20CORP. "Moose Toys Pty Ltd v. Thriftway BLVD. Drug Corp,{{check quotation}}<!-- MISSING " following: -->"] Legale Inc, Retrieved 16 January 2016.</ref>
==Media== Shopkins served as inspiration for a design challenge on [[Project Runway (season 16)|season 16]] of [[Project Runway]].<ref>http://www.mylifetime.com/shows/project-runway/season-16/episode-9</ref>
==See also== * [[Moose Toys]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Spectra'' (installation)}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:Spectra above chimney tops.png|thumb|upright|''spectra [london]'', 2014. The beam could be seen for miles above the rooftops and chimneys of London.]] '''''Spectra''''' is the name of a series of art [[installation art|installations]] by [[Ryoji Ikeda]] which use intense white light as a sculptural material.<ref name=RI/> The most recent presentation of ''spectra'' was in Hobart, Tasmania, Australia for four days ending 24 June, 2018 to mark the winter solstice, and as an installation piece at the [[MONA_FOMA|Dark Mofo]] festival held by [[Museum_of_Old_and_New_Art|MONA]]. ''spectra [Amsterdam]'' was the first presentation of the work in 2008 its current form; an array of xenon lamps pointed skywards lit from dusk till dawn accompanied by a mathematically derived score audible from each of the lamp bases. The work was first commissioned and produced by Forma Arts.
==History== Ryoji Ikeda has produced ''spectra'' installations in a number of locations, all in several different configurations. The first was a tunnel of light and sound at [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK Airport]] at Eero Saarinen's abandoned TWA Terminal in New York in 2004.<ref name=RI/> Four site-specific light and sound installations were created across [[Amsterdam]] in 2008 for the city's ''Dream Amsterdam'' event.<ref name=RI/> A more concentrated 64-beam installation was then created in Paris that year for their annual ''[[Nuit Blanche]]'' festival.<ref name=RI/> Other cities which have hosted the installation include [[Buenos Aires]], [[Hobart]],<ref name="HobartABC">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/arts/stories/s3782288.htm |title=Artists cover Hobart in white light for the opening of Dark Mofo - News - ABC Arts | Australian contemporary art and culture reviews, news & videos |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2013-06-14 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> and [[Nagoya]].<ref name=RI>{{citation |url=http://www.ryojiikeda.com/project/spectra/ |title=spectra | year=2010 |author=Ryoji Ikeda}}</ref>
==''spectra [tasmania]'', 2013 & 2018== [[File:Spectra & Full Moon from Mt Wellington (9111132653).jpg|thumbnail|''spectra [tasmania]'' pierces the [[Hobart]] Skyline, 22 June 2013.]] ''spectra [tasmania]'' was an installation of 49 Xenon searchlights. It was placed in front of [[Hobart Cenotaph|Hobart's Cenotaph]] on the western shore of that city's central business district. Installed and active from sunset to sunrise 14 - 23 June 2013 as part of The Red Queen, a group exhibition for 1st Dark Mofo Festival. It was estimated to reach 5-15km into the sky, depending on the weather.<ref name="HobartABC"/> In 2018 it was displayed from the grounds of MONA (Museum of Old and New Art) with the addition of Ikeda's accompanying soundscape, where it was confirmed that plans were in place to house ''spectra'' at the museum permanently.
==''spectra [london]'', 2014== [[File:Spectra London.jpg|thumb|Spectra London, Victoria Tower Gardens]] The London installation consisted similarly of 49 Xenon searchlights shining together into the sky, accompanied by a [[soundscape]]. This presentation of ''Spectra'' was produced and presented by [[Artangel]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artangel.org.uk/projects/2014/spectra/about_the_project/spectra |title=Ryoji Ikeda: spectra |publisher=Artangel |date=2014-08-11 |accessdate=2015-08-12}}</ref> and co-commissioned by [[Mayor of London]] [[Boris Johnson]] and the [[14-18 NOW]] programme of the [[Imperial War Museum]] for the [[First World War centenary|centenary of World War One]].<ref name=DT/><ref name=G/> and funded by the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]]. It was switched on at the end of the Lights Out event on 4 August 2014, when the lights of many buildings in the UK were turned off in recollection of [[Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon|Sir Edward Grey]]'s famous prophecy that, "[[The lamps are going out|The lamps are going out all over Europe;]] we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime."<ref name=BBC>{{citation |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-28655977 |title=WW1 centenary: Column of light illuminates London commemoration |publisher=BBC News |date=5 August 2014}}</ref> The installation was turned off for good at dawn on 11 August 2014, as the presentation was only planned to last for one week.<ref name=DT>{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/11013386/ArtAngel-spectra-Londons-centenary-beam-of-light.html |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |title=ArtAngel spectra: London's centenary beam of light |author=Richard Dorment |date=5 August 2014}}</ref>
The spotlights used were [[xenon arc lamp]]s requiring 4 kilowatts of power each.<ref name=G/> The array and the sound system was powered by four [[diesel generator]]s fuelled by [[biodiesel|vegetable oil]].<ref name=G/> A crew of thirty technicians assembled, tested and maintained the installation.<ref name=G>{{citation |title=Spectra: the dazzling column of light over London |author=Sean O'Hagan |newspaper=The Guardian |date=5 August 2014 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/aug/05/ryoji-ikeda-spectra-first-world-war-artangel}}</ref> The soundscape was inspired by mathematical concepts and consisted of pure [[sine wave]]s.<ref name=1418N>{{citation |url=http://www.1418now.org.uk/lights-out/artist/ryoji-ikeda/ |title=Spectra Ryoji Ikeda|work=Lights Out |publisher=[[14-18 NOW]] |year=2014}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery mode=packed> Crowds come to Spectra.jpg |Crowds are drawn to the nightly spectacle in London Spectra close-up.jpg |Spectators can get in amongst the lights in London Spectra by the Victoria Tower.jpg|The base of the London installation was in [[Victoria Tower Gardens]] Spectra London 2.jpg|Spectra London Spectra London 3.jpg|Looking up towards the sky while standing in the middle of Spectra London Spectra London 4.jpg|Spectra London Spectra London 5.jpg|Spectra London </gallery>
==See also== * [[Cathedral of light]], a 1937 Nazi propaganda display with massed searchlights pointing skyward * [[Luxor Hotel#Beam|Luxor Hotel and Casino skybeam]], currently the world's brightest searchlight display * [[A Symphony of Lights]], a light display across Hong Kong harbour * [[Tribute in Light]], a memorial of the 11 September attack on the World Trade Centre
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Spectra (Ryoji Ikeda)}} *[http://www.artangel.org.uk/ Artangel] – the collective which produced ''spectra [London]'' 2014 *[http://www.forma.org.uk/ Forma Arts] - the creative producing agency that commissioned and produced ''spectra'' *[http://www.ryojiikeda.com/ Ryoji Ikeda] - artist responsible for ''spectra''
